an5.136:1.1: “Mendicants, an anointed aristocratic king’s eldest son with five factors aspires to become a viceroy.
an5.136:1.3: It’s when an anointed aristocratic king’s eldest son is well born on both his mother’s and father’s side, of pure descent, with irrefutable and impeccable genealogy back to the seventh paternal generation.
an5.136:1.4: He is attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty.
an5.136:1.5: He is dear and beloved to his parents.
an5.136:1.6: He is dear and beloved to the armed forces.
an5.136:1.7: He is astute, competent, and intelligent, able to think issues through as they bear upon the past, future, and present.
an5.136:2.6: dear and beloved to my parents …
an5.136:2.8: dear and beloved to the armed forces …
an5.136:2.10: I’m astute, competent, and intelligent, able to think issues through as they bear upon the past, future, and present.
an5.136:2.11: Why shouldn’t I aspire to become a viceroy?’
an5.136:2.12: An anointed aristocratic king’s eldest son with these five factors aspires to become a viceroy.
an5.136:3.1: In the same way, a mendicant with five qualities aspires to end the defilements.
an5.136:3.3: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
an5.136:3.4: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s totally full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reciting them, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically.
an5.136:3.5: Their mind is firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
an5.136:3.6: They live with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.
an5.136:3.7: They’re wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.
an5.136:4.10: wise. I have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.
an5.136:4.11: Why shouldn’t I aspire to end the defilements?’
an5.136:4.12: A mendicant with these five qualities aspires to end the defilements.”
